review_title: If you're looking to grow professionally don't come here
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: There are some decent people who work here and the work that the organization tries to do is great.
cons:
Senior management is disorganized and stuck doing things the way they were done 20 years ago. There's no real interest in innovation or evolving to how most similar organizations now conduct business. 

No opportunity for growth or career advancement. They say when you come on that they allow for this but once you try to do anything they immediately try to shut it down. No understanding of why you would want to do anything other than your job responsibilities or grow professionally.

It's a very miserable environment to work in. Everything is very silo-ed. There's virtually no community or interaction among staff that goes on. Having even a five minute conversation with someone gets you the side eye from some of the staff. If you're looking for some place to enjoy going to work, this won't be it.

There's also very little loyalty at the organization. They have a track record of handling layoffs and the like very poorly.

pros:
My colleagues were all fantastic - smart, friendly, and eager to help out those early in their careers. There is a really friendly and family-like atmosphere to the organization, which is often discussed as a reason employees stay with the organization for multiple years. Unlike many other similar NGOs, this work-place vibe isn't abused to ask employees to put in crazy hours or make sacrifices. I found all my colleagues to have and promote a great work-life balance, and my personal life was never (not once!) encroached on by work.

HKI does great international nutrition programming and is constantly seeking to improve. I gained invaluable international experience working at a regional office, and mentors/contacts that I will continue to reach out to for networking and advice as I progress in my career. HKI is well respected in the iNGO and nutrition world and my opinion of them only improved by spending time at the organization.
cons: There is some disorganization (both logistical, as well as differences in goals and problem-solving approaches) between the country, regional and headquarters office in NYC. The organization as a whole could be more effective and efficient if they better utilized technology and their employees skills. I certainly could have handled a larger workload and more responsibilities.

pros: Outstanding mission with people who truly care about exacting change. The organization truly puts helping others first, with all funds really going towards helping those less fortunate rather than skimming $ off the top.
cons:
If you want to work in an office where you literally don't interact or speak to anyone the entire day except via email, this is the place for you. When arriving at the office, no one would bother glancing up long enough to even say hello. The place is totally silent except for the clatter of keyboards. It made dragging myself to work every day almost intolerable. 

It is truly a shame the office environment is so draining and depressing since the work being done there is so stellar. I guess that is the payoff for the long, stressful hours toiling away in dark cubicles.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Some very genuine and helpful people.
cons:
Management is insensitive and treats employees poorly, especially new employees who have not established “history” with the company.  Those in management tend to have “favorites” because those individuals are very friendly and gossipy with them.  Working late hours to help catch up does not count for anything; management will not be flexible with adjusting your hours like many companies would.  Management is not appreciative of hard working staff willing to go beyond what is asked of them to get things done and always seem to find something you did not finish or did not do to use it against you.  If you are told that you are hired based on your expertise and will get to use your experience to help improve the organization.  Scratch that out of your mind!!  Once you start your job and try to do so, you will get shut down.  It is only all talk and no action!!  Not to mention, there is very little transparency and accountability by management.  Get ready to be detested for trying to improve on things and be micro-managed on everything from the way you organize your emails down to how you staple/organize your paperwork!!  Do not bother speaking up at meetings when asked about inefficiencies or areas for improvement, management won’t take you seriously.  Anyone who voices a different opinion or concern from management will end up on a target list of getting picked on.  Anything you do after giving plenty of “good ideas” your work ends up under a microscope with lots of scrutiny.  Rather than feeling like you are part of a team, you will feel isolated and bullied.  Management will constantly twist things you said to make you look insubordinate, which not only makes you feel unwelcome; you end up second guessing yourself and your work.  Also, god forbid if you have a question about your work (not even a suggestion on improvement) you will get the cold shoulder and made feeling incompetent.  Do not even try going to HR for help regarding such issues because HR sides with Management.  Management is not good at “managing” but with HR protecting Management, things will not change.  Management is stuck doing things the way they were done since the 1980s and has no interest in changing even with the looming deadline of a cloud based software system being implemented.

The office is dark, outdated and dead silent most of the time.  All you will hear is the clattering of keyboards all day long.  It is depressing that you cannot make friends at work.  You will get the evil eye from some staff if you have a conversation with anyone about things not work related and those same individuals are very friendly with Management that eavesdrop on everyone’s conversations.  You need to be chummy with Management if you want advancement and be recognized for your work.  Otherwise, don’t even think about asking for anything from Management.  It is a very clique-ish type of work place and it feels like a prison!!
